div.p: Alpheus Spear came and paid me 205 dollars for the Quarters Rent of the Mount Wollaston farm to the 30th. of June— Morning visits from the Sisters Mercy and Susan Tufts—and afternoon visits from Mr William Minot and Charles P. Curtis— There has been for two or three years a project for a general association of the graduates of Harvard University, to hold annual meetings the day before Commencement, intentionally as a substitute for the Meetings and Literary exercises of the Phi Beta Kappa Society, the day after Commencement— The day before the last Commencement there was a Meeting of the Alumni, at which a Committee of 5 were appointed to prepare and report at the day before the ensuing Commencement a plan for such a general association. Mr Minot and Mr Curtis are members of that Committee, and came to enquire, if I would consent to be put in nomination for the Office of President of the Society— I felt myself honoured by the proposal and said I had only two objections against it— One the consciousness of my inefficiency for the Office; and the other a warm regard for the Phi beta kappa Society, and an aversion to join in any measure which would seem to have a bearing of hostility to them. They said that the members of the Phi beta kappa society had themselves originated the proposal of the general association, and almost universally favoured it— Mr Curtis read to me the report, to be made including a Constitution for the new Society— A President, two Vice-Presidents and 7. Directors are proposed for the organization of the Society— Judge Story and Edward Everett are proposed for Vice Presidents— I consented to place my name at their disposal— Josiah Quincy and his Lady came up on horseback and held a colloquy with Mrs Charles at Sunset, before the porch of her house.
Sun rose at 5.10— Set 6:56.—both in haze.

I saw Sirius, about half an hour risen, immediately after I rose— Then the rising Sun from the South-eastern corner of Charles’s house, and the setting Sun, from his porch— Morning visit from two Officers of the Navy: Lieutenants Wilson and M’Neill, stationed as they told me, at the Navy-yard in Charlestown. Afternoon visits from Mr and Mrs Armstrong, and from Baron Maréchal, the Austrian Minister at Washington—with Mr Austin the Attorney General of the Commonwealth— I enquired of the Baron what we were to think of these rumours of Wars between France and England; brought by the last Steamers, from Liverpool, the Acadia, which arrived on Monday at Boston, after a passage of 12 days and 14 hours and the President arrived yesterday in 17 days at New-York— The Baron thinks there is no danger of War; and that the large armament of Louis-Philippe, is merely a demonstration of Louis-Philippe to put a responsibility upon his Minister, and thereby to get rid of him— The first part of the Evening I spent under Charles’s porch with him and Mr Lunt— Afterwards his wife and then himself were at our house— I attempt in vain to economise time for writing beyond the Diary of the day, and one short Letter— I despatched two packages with 50 copies in each of my revenue-bill Speech, to John Fine, Member of H.R.U.S. at Ogdensburg, St. Lawrence County, New-York, and an answer to an invitation from Samuel Lawrence, to address a public whig meeting at Lowell, which I declined— I continue the daily reading of about 20 pages of the 4th. volume of Grahame’s History of the United States, with which I am much less satisfied with than with the preceding volumes. The narrative until the close of the 7 years war and the conquest of Canada continues interesting, and in all the approaches or premonitory symptoms of the conflict between the Mother Britain and the Colonies, the bias of the Historian in favour of the Americans is constant and overruling— In the Appendix 3. p. 147. Is a statement with a proper mark of reprobation, that in the year 1764 there was despatched from England to America a pack of blood-hounds to assist the British troops in tracking the Indians— He says that the British never stooped to the employment of such auxiliaries, except in their contests with Indians, or with negro slaves.— There is some account from Soskiel of the Moravian Missions— The title of the 11th. Book is, the Progress of the States of North-America, till their Assumption of political Independence— The first chapter contains the account of the commercial restrictions subsequent to the Peace of 1763. and of the Stamp-act—but not a word about the argument in the case of the Writs of Assistance.— Grahame never saw the Massachusetts State Papers, nor Novanglus.

Morning visit from Mr Thomas Loring and Mr Edward Thaxter of Hingham, who came to propose a fishing party at Cohassett some day next week, of which Mr Loring will give me due notice. Deacon spear came as by appointment at 4 this afternoon with his waggon, in which I went with him and my Son and his Son Charles up into the pastures beyond the two houses of the brothers Ebenezer and Josiah Adams, on the spot where stood the old family mansion of Joseph Adams junr. father of my grandfather John Adams. The youngest Son of this Joseph was Ebenezer, and he as has been usual in New-England inherited the family mansion and farm.— It is the old borough—English tenure, the reason of which is fully developed in the natural origin of it, by the law of nature operating upon the state of Society consequent upon the colonization of New-England— The settlers at Mount Wollaston received small grants of land proportioned to the number of heads in each family— As the children grew up to man’s estate— The sons one after another, and the daughters by marriage departed from the paternal fire-side, and went abroad to find new Settlements for themselves leaving the youngest son, to cultivate the farm with the father, and to hold possession of it after his decease.— Thus it was that the first Joseph, the youngest Son, or youngest but one, of the Patriarch Henry, being only 20 years of age, at his death in 1646. inherited the malt house and brewery, which he occupied through a long life and left to his youngest Son Peter— The elder Son, Joseph junr had emigrated from the brew house, and pitched on this spot, a little hermitage remote from the high way; which in 1736, he dying, left to his youngest Son, Ebenezer, whose Son of the same name was, the father of the two brothers, who now at ages of 79 and 77. are still in common possession of the Estate— We found Deacon Josiah at work on his Potato field, and he walked with us to view the ground staked out for the road, from Braintree to the borders of Milton— As usual it trenches largely on my land, and passes very near to the houses of the two brothers— On returning home I found at our door Mr Solomon Lincoln of Hingham, and Mr Fearing, originally of Hingham, but now of Boston— Mr Lincoln enquired whether I should be a candidate for re-election, and whether I proposed to attend any of the public Meetings in the District preparatory to the November elections. I said I did not intend to be present at any of the public meetings; and that whether I should be a candidate for re-election or not would depend upon the people of the District themselves— I should not offer myself; nor should I decline—especially as for the first time since I have represented the district, a formal and avowed opposition to my re-election was announced. He then enquired if I proposed to address the People of the District through the Newspapers as I have heretofore done.— I said I thought I should— Charles spent the Evening here— His wife was unwell, and did not come down.

My namesake and nephew, the midshipman was here last Evening—his Sister Elizabeth returned two days before from her visit to Cedar grove Fishkill landing where she went to be present at the wedding of Louisa de Wint, now Mrs Whittemore. She came home sick, and has been confined to the house ever since— This morning Charless wife with her daughter Louisa-Catherine went into Boston, and thence to Medford, where she is to spend a week at her father’s. She took Mrs Frothingham’s son Ward with her—he has been a week of school vacation with her boys here— Mrs Kirk and Mary Louisa, went also with her; and Charles; but they all returned before dinner, and Charles and the two elder boys dined and took tea with us. I have received a Letter from Mr Samuel Cabot of Boston, saying that his Sister widow of the late Professor Follen who lost his life in the melancholy catastrophe of the Lexington Steamer last Winter—is about to publish some account of his life—and that she desires to publish part of a Letter which he wrote to me in 1831. October upon German Literature— And if I have preserved the Letter, she asks for it, for that purpose. This put me upon the search for my files of Letters of the last ten years, which I found in the great confusion, and after the waste of at least three hours, I was yet unable to find the files of 1831— This is an admonition which I must not disregard to pursue connectedly the determination to assort all my manuscript papers so as to have them at my command— The only step towards which that I could now take was to gather and file upon two steel rings the keys of 14 wooden chests in which most of my manuscript papers are contained— Eleven of these chests are now here, and three at Washington; one of them packed up, and expected soon here— We had this afternoon a very heavy thunder gust differing from those which usually happen at this Season: the shower coming first and the thunder and lightening afterwards— It came up very suddenly and the clouds at no time of it wholly covered the sky. Mrs John Codman, wife of the orthodox minister at Dorchester, was passing by, with Miss Allen, daughter of the President of Dartmouth college, and stop’d with us until the storm was over; about an hour— Mrs Codman gave us an affecting account of the last sickness and recent death of Mr Samuel Adams Welles, only grandson of Samuel Adams, who has left ready for the press a Life of his grand-father with vouchers to comprize Six Octavo Volumes— Mr Welles’s last 3 years have been a period of excruciating pains and after the amputation of a leg, a long agony of death. I saw the Sunset from Charles’s porch, and he spent the Evening here— The atmosphere was more sultry after the shower than before— Answered the Letter of C. A. Luzenberg—President of the Louisiana Society of Natural History and Sciences.
Sun rose 5:14.— Barely visible through haze.

Afternoon visits from Mr Smith, the preceptor of the Hingham Academy, with the two Misses Thaxter, and afterwards from the Revd. Mr Lothrop with Mr John Forbes, second son of Ralph Bennett Forbes, and of his widow, sister of Thomas H. Perkins, who visited us on the 5th. instt. with another John Forbes, not as I then supposed him her Son; but of James Grant Forbes, another brother of my old deceased friend and Classmate John Murray Forbes— Ralph Bennet Forbes my Classmate’s younger brother was like himself a martyr to the gout, and in his last days, dependent, with his family upon his brother John for support— But Ralph Bennet’s eldest Son, of the same name went out very young to China, and in a very few years made an affluent fortune— This John was also there and alike successful.— They came back, and built for their mother the elegant house on Milton hill where she now resides. John built and resides in a cottage near the same spot— But Ralph after his return was unfortunate, became poor again, and went again to China, to reinstate himself in prosperity— He is yet there, unless expelled with the other American Merchants from Canton, in consequence of the Opium quarrel between the English and the Chinese. Mr John Forbes is in great anxiety on his brother’s account, and asked many questions of my opinions, both with regard to facts and principles, involved in this controversy— I told him I was very imperfectly informed of the facts; that I could not possibly bring myself to believe that the British would attempt the conquest of China; and I believed that their demonstration of War, was made merely for effecting an accommodation with the Chinese Government upon as good terms as they could obtain, but that if they do pursue the War they will suffer no neutral commerce with China, and that all the American commercial establishments at Canton will be broken up. He asked if they had the right? I answered no, but that in commercial warfare, the British measure of right was power; and they had no other— He said that many persons entertained the opinion that a British army of 15000 men, the force which they have ordered there, will easily accomplish the conquest of all China; there being no organized military force, and the people having no weapons except bows and arrows. I said that with such an immense population, invasion itself would soon organise a defensive military force, and if they should have no other weapons than the stones of the Streets they would be sufficient to crush a European army of 15000 men. He said he had, and would send me a published statement of the facts—
Sun rose invisible Hazy Horizon. Clear above.

Mr Lunt preached this morning from 2 Timothy 2.5. “And if a man also, strive for masteries, yet is he not crowned, except he strive lawfully.” This was his third discourse against the new, or old vamped up transcendental doctrines— He waxes warm as he proceeds, and gave this day a broadside at Carlyle without naming him for having in his history of the French Revolution, dressed up the character of Mirabeau into a pattern of patriotism— The deadly sophistry of the transcendental school consists in the alliance of Atheism with hypocrisy.— The characteristic of the age is to unsettle all established opinions, and to put into perpetual question all the foundations of human Society— We are to argue pro and con—whether parricide be a crime or a virtue; whether property, is by the law of Nature, or the mere creature of conventional law—whether the contract of marriage constitutes an obligation of duty restrictive of promiscuous social intercourse—in short whether justice or force is at the root of all human institutions— In the process of this argument the transcendentals not only dig up the cornerstones of human Society; but pronounce them decayed, rotten and worthless— The dregs and the froth of the cauldron are boiled up into one impure and poisonous compound and administered to the body politic for healing medicine.— Religion is sapped and undermined by this fraudulent philosophy; the labouring classes are instigated to hatred and violence against the proprietors, and the elements of a civil war of extermination, are stimulated into deadly conflict with one another— Mr Lunt has not yet finished with this subject, but with discourse upon it again— Mr Whitney preached in the afternoon, from Job 14.14.— “All the days of my appointed time will I wait, till my change come.”— Upon Death— Mr Whitney has been forty years the settled minister of this Church and Congregation, and he cannot have long to wait for his change— The marks of age are sinking upon him deeper and deeper, every day. The argument of his discourse that Death was not to be dreaded as an evil, but as the necessary proper, and happily devised termination of life, which must of course have an end.— I read two Sermons of Barrow—the second upon quietness, and doing our own business—and the first upon the Love of God.— The following extract is from the Discourse on quietness. “Especially we should not make ourselves parties, in any faction, where both sides are eager and passionate, for then, even they who have the juster cause, are wont to do unjust things in which, it is hard for any man engaged not to have share, at least not to undergo the imputation of them: it is wisdom therefore in such cases, to hold off, and to retain a kind of indifferency; to meddle with them is (as the Wise man saith) to take a dog by the ears; which he that doth, can hardly take care enough of his fingers.”— What a seasonable admonition to me! Charles spent the Evening here. We had two ends of thunder showers, refreshing the air, which has been at sultry Summer heat the last three days.

Elizabeth C. Adams, dined and spent the day here, and went home this Evening— Her mother went last week to Medford, and is yet there. Charles went to Boston and to Medford, to return with his wife to-morrow— There was a light thunder shower in the course of this day; I had no interruptions of visitors or of business, and yet passed an unprofitable day— I despatched a parcel of my pamphlet discourses, with a Letter to I. K Tefft corresponding Secretary of the Georgia Historical Society, in answer, and return to a Diploma received from him a few days since, as an honorary member of that Society, with the first volume of their Transactions.— My attempts to arrange and assort my files of Letters for the last ten years have as yet only involved them in greater confusion— I have not found the files of 1831. but in assorting alphabetically the files of summer and Autumn of 1834, which on my sudden, and terrible call to Washington to witness the last moments of my dear and ever lamented son John I had left in chaotic disorder here, and had until now, never since inspected, I found, out of place, and time, the very Letter from Charles Follen, 1. Decr. 1831. for which the Letter from Mr Samuel Cabot, received last week had set me, upon the search— I enclosed and despatched it this day to Mr Cabot— I have a Letter from the Revd. Josiah Adams of Parkersburgh Virginia, containing some genealogical enquiries— I began a Letter in answer to him, which I intended should not exceed five lines, but in which I was interrupted to view from Charles’s porch the setting of the Sun; for which, clear and beautiful as it was, I was not quite a Sun’s disk too late. My Miscellaneous and involuntary reading continues desultory as ever— I have now just read Milton’s Areopagitica; A Speech for the Liberty of unlicensed printing—to the Parliament of England— This speech was not delivered but published in 1645. against an order of the Rump Parliament, prohibiting all publications without the imprimatur—published he says as a certain testimony if not a trophy of his Country’s Liberty— [“]For this is not the Liberty which we can hope, that no grievance ever should arise in the Commonwealth, that let no man in this world expect; but when complaints are freely heard, deeply considered and speedily reformed, then is the utmost bound of civil liberty attained that wise men look for.”— The argument against restrictions upon the press is founded on two principles & authority—the practice of all republican Government, before that time having been adverse to such restrictions—and 2. that the corrections of the abuses of the press belong to the pulpit and not to legislation. The style is throughout oratorical, repeatedly addressing the imaginary auditory in the second person— Lords and Commons of England!— The discourse is replete with beautiful imagery, and fortified with cogent argument; though in antiquated language.— The writers and speakers of modern English can derive little benefit from any of the composers of that age, and from none less than from Milton.

I went to Boston in the Carriage alone, and took with me the 4th. volume of Grahame’s history of the United States to pass the time— I stop’d first at Dr Frothingham’s, but he was not at home— At Charles’s office I found Mr Nathaniel Curtis, and Charles himself soon after came in from Medford— Mr Spooner was also there— I went with Mr Curtis, to the probate office, where was the judge, Willard Phillips, and Mr Fuller the Administrator upon the Estates of the two Moses Gill’s— A question had remained over upon the allowance by the judge last November of my Account as Administrator de bonis non, with the Will annexed of Thomas Boylston, whether the amount of the Note of the second Moses Gill to Mrs Boylston of 5. Jany 1830. for 984 dollars 78 cents with interest should be deducted from the sum to be paid over by me to the Representative of the Gill’s— Mr Fuller still doubted whether as Administrator, he could consent to this deduction, without making himself liable to the creditors who had claims on the Gill estates. I then made a conditional offer, to relinquish on the part of Mr Boylston, the interest upon the Note amounting to 860:63. and the allowance of 600 dollars made by the judge to me as Administrator, if after deducting the amount of the Note I should be authorised to pay over the remainder to Mr Fuller for the heirs of the last Moses Gill—but I added this was not to be understood if the amount to be paid over by me, would go, not to the last Moses Gill’s heirs, but to claimants upon his or his uncle’s Estates, of the validity or justice of which I knew nothing. The judge urged the acceptance of this offer upon Mr Fuller, and said it could easily be accomplished in legal form—but Mr Fuller declined doing any thing without advice of Counsel— The judge therefore adjourned his decision to some future day, to be notified hereafter— I then went to Mr T. W. Ward’s Office; and returned to his clerk Mr Story, the single order for £10 Sterling, upon the Brothers Baring and Co. London, for which he returned to me the 50 dollar Bill, which he had taken for it— I went to the Store of P. and S. Sprague. 13. Commercial Wharf, and there received a set of three Bills at 3 days sight on the same Baring’s payable to me or my order, and upon which Mr Phineas Sprague gave me 2 dollars and 12 1/2 cents change for the 50 dollar Bill— I attended at Noon a Meeting of the Massachusetts Historical Society, where numerous donations were received and the Chevalier Friederichsthal was elected a foreign member.— I went to Dr Frothingham’s, where I found Mrs Charles, returned from Medford with her daughter Louisa-Catherine— Charles and his wife, returned to Quincy before dinner— I called to see Mr Abbott Lawrence, just returned from the white Sulphur Virginia Springs, with his family very little improved in health.— R. G. Shaw, Dr Sewall of Washington, and Revd. Andrew Bigelow were there. I dined at T. L. Winthrop’s.— Met there Mrs George Sullivan—General Miller from South-America, George Bancroft and about 15 others— Thunder gust— After dinner I took up Charles’s daughter Louisa at Dr Frothingham’s, and returned to Quincy at the dusk of Evening.

Mr Loring from Hingham was here this morning with two young girls from Pawtucket visitors at Hingham, one of them a relative of Joseph L. Tillinghast the member of Congress from Rhode-Island— Mr Loring said they had fixed upon the day after tomorrow for the fishing party at Cohasset; and I promised to be at Hingham at 6 or half past 6 that day— I had much conversation yesterday with Mr Bancroft, upon the third volume of his History of the United States which is shortly to come out; and of which he told me that my father would be the hero— But I have learnt to estimate the assurances of Mr Bancroft at their value— I promised to shew him the original Letter of my father to Nathan Webb of October 1755. and the minutes of his journal upon his argument before the Governor and Council on the 18th. of Decr 1765. as one of the Counsel of the Town of Boston, upon their petition for the opening of the Courts of Justice without the use of stamps.— Mrs Lawrence had written me a note, inviting my company at her son’s rooms at Commencement this day— I called at their house yesterday to than her for the invitation, and offer my excuses, not intending to go to commencement— And I gave the same answer to Mr R. G Shaw, who gave me an invitation to the rooms of his Son, also to be graduated this day. I dined this day with my Son, and was conversing with him after dinner upon Plautus and his Translators French and English, when Mr E. Price Greenleaf came in with a copy of a Resolution, which he said had been adopted at a large whig meeting, that a committee be appointed to wait on me, and inform me that it is the wish of the whigs at Quincy, to invite the whigs of the 12th. congressional District, in particular, and the Electors generally to meet with them in Quincy, on an appointed day agreeable to me, to pay their respects to me, and request me, to favour them with an Address on the present state of the country, the present administration of the national government, and the prospects of the whig party— I told Mr Greenleaf that I was greatly obliged to the whigs of the town, for their kind proposal, and especially for the personal accommodation to me intended by calling the meeting here; but that I had already declined attending at a similar meeting to which I had been invited to be held at Rochester in the County of Plymouth, and at many others out of the District— I stated the reasons which had induced me to decline attendance at all the recent meetings considering it a duty resulting from my peculiar situation, and desired him to make them known to the whigs of Quincy, and suggest to them the wish that they would receive this informal answer rather than by sending a formal committee cause the necessity for a written answer from me for publication of my reasons, some of which were rather to be felt than argued— He said he would satisfy the whigs entirely with my answer.— Charles’s wife was very unwell all this day—and could not spend the evening with us— Charles himself did.
At sun rising— Set in cloud—clear above.

I had intended to go this day to Cambridge, to attend the Boylston prize Declamations and the ΦB.K Oration— But as the time came the spirit failed, and I concluded to stay at home— My purpose was to have improved the hours; but except the record of the last two days, I only finished the reading of Grahame’s History of the United States— The day brought a continual succession of visitors— First Mrs T. Greenleaf with Mrs and a Miss Warren— Then a Messenger with a note from Thomas Adams junr. requesting a Letter of introduction to Mr Cushing of Newburyport, to whom he is to bear a Letter of invitation from the Ladies of Quincy to the Whig Pic Nic here, next Thursday— I gave the Letter and then called and made a deposit at the Quincy Stone Bank— Returning home I stop’d at Charles’s house to see his wife who was quite unwell— She was in her chamber, on her couch, but bearing up in spirits— Mary was with her— Charles gone to Boston, but returned to dine.— After dinner visits from Edward and Mrs Brooks and their niece Miss Wells—short— But they passed the afternoon at Charles’s— Then the two Misses Baxter— Their mother and their Sister Mrs Lee, are both much indisposed— Two wandering travellers from Easton, Pennsylvania followed; came to see me and the rocky ledges and railway; the curiosities of the place— Nightengale introduced himself and his companion by the name of Heim, or Hinds— Next came Thomas J. Noyes— He says he lives on Penn’s Hill in Braintree. He left with me a copy of a Petition, of his Grandmother Mary Pike of Bennington Genessee County, New-York, for a Pension, as widow and relict of Simeon Pike of Haverhill, Massachusetts who was killed at the Battle of Bunker’s Hill 17. June 1775. He had been enlisted for eight months but was killed before he had served six months— The father of this Thomas J. Noyes, married the daughter of Mrs Pike, and she now lives with him— The Petition has already been presented to the House, and I promised if I live to attend the next Session of Congress to call it up, and have it referred, with the authenticated vouchers, to the Committee on Revolutionary pensions, and to do all in my power to obtain the pension for this poor woman who is now 87. years old and a cripple. Dr. Woodward was here to visit Louisa C. Smith, who is again seriously indisposed— In the Evening, Elizabeth C. Adams was here, with her brother the Midshipman andFoster— Her mother has returned from Medford also unwell— Charles was also here, but his wife was confined at home.

At half past five this morning, I left home in a Gig, with my son, and went to Mr Thomas Loring’s at Hingham where we breakfasted; with him and a Mr and Mrs Sprague living in his house; another young woman was also there, and the two little girls who came with him to Quincy on Wednesday. After breakfast I went with Mr Loring in his Gig, and the Revd. Mr Stearns with my Son to the small shed at Cohasset, whence we had been upon a fishing party last Summer. A small party soon assembled there now, and six or eight of us embarked from the rocks in a good sized Sail-boat and went out between four and five miles from the shore, and fished for cod and haddock—we changed our position once and caught about 30 fishes, of which I took nine.— At one O’Clock we brought the boat round and returned to the rocks. I should have liked much to continue fishing three hours longer, but the rest of the company were weary and sharp set for dinner, and impatient to return, to which I interposed no obstacle— The Revd. Mr Stearns, Minister of the Parish where Mr Charles Brooks was settled, Dr. John Brazer of Salem with his twin sons John and William, boys about twelve years of age, were of our party— The Chowder dinner company at the shed were about 30 in number among whom were Solomon, and Jotham and Jairus Lincoln, Edward Thaxter James C Doane and others whose names I could not retain— The Revd. Dr W. P. Greenwood, seemed to be in the last stage of a consumption.— After the chowder and some general conversation, I walked an hour with Dr Brazer and Mr Loring to and upon the beach; on returning from which we had a second dinner of fried fish and lemonade, after which I returned with Mr Loring to his house at Hingham, where by his invitation the whole company repaired together with Mr Josiah Quincy junr. and his Son Josiah, who had come at 6 in the evening instead of 6 in the morning, as he had been invited— We took tea at Mr Loring’s and with the light of a bright Aurora Borealis returned home, and alighted at my gate just before the 9. O’Clock Evening Bell.— There was a cold morning fog barely sufficient to discolour the Sun till we reached Cohasset—then a clear sky, smooth water and alternate calm and cool eastern breeze, barely enough to curl the surface of the glass; as fine an autumnal day as the earth ever rolled round her axis— The distant shores of Gloucester and Cape Ann and Gloucester, and the Light house at the entrance of Boston harbour on one side, and the Scituate meeting house on the other bounded the horizon, with the boundless Ocean, dotted with numerous spots of white canvas all over the scene— Mr Loring and Solomon Lincoln told me that the abolitionists of the 12th. Congressional District had held a meeting last Tuesday at Hanover twelve persons present and nominated Seth Sprague junr. as their Candidate for the 27th Congress— That the administration party would nominate John B. Turner, and that Joseph Morton Jackson the old Candidate for the present Congress would be set aside to his sore disappointment.

div.p: This Mr Bradley, from New-Haven, Connecticut is a travelling Book-peddler, a very common occupation in New England— He brought with him Barber’s historical collections—of Massachusetts—a useful work of minute geography and history of which I gave my name as a subscriber, and took a copy— Mr John Whitney called, and thanked me for my contribution, upon the occasion of the fire which last autumn consumed his house.— He said it had been so heavy a blow to him at the time, that he had been almost discouraged; but he had now got upon his feet again, and was doing pretty well. I planted in the seminary the plumstones of the fruit brought from Mr Downing’s at Newburgh by Elizabeth C. Adams; and the four stones of the early Ann peach which we have this year from the tree— Mr Thomas P. Beal alighted from the Plymouth stage and spent an hour with me under great political excitement— The whole country throughout the Union is in a state of agitation upon the approaching presidential election such as was never before witnessed.— From the organization of the Government under the present Constitution of the United States, the nominations of Candidates for the Office of President were made in Caucus Convention by members of Congress—and by the members of the State Legislatures. The Congressional Caucus nomination of 1824 was in favour of William H. Crawford, and signally failed.— The State Legislature nominations produced only cross purposes; and have been superseded by party popular conventions, increasing in numbers till that of last May at Baltimore of the young men, to confirm the nomination of W. H. Harrison made before, by a select Caucus Convention at Harrisburg, Pennsylvania, last December, amounted it was said to twenty thousand delegates— This has been followed by numerous assemblages in all the States where the opposition is in any strength, and not a week has passed within the last four months without a convocation of thousands of people, to hear inflammatory harangues against Martin Van Buren and his administration, by Henry Clay, Daniel Webster, and all the principal opposition Orators in or out of Congress— I received earnest invitations to attend these Meetings and address the People at Nashville, Tennessee, Chillicothe Ohio, Wheeling Virginia, Baltimore, Alexandria, Georgetown, and many other places, all of which I declined both from general principles and from considerations specially and peculiarly applicable to myself— One of these assemblies was held yesterday by a public dinner given to Caleb Cushing by some of his constituents at Newburyport, and a Ball in the evening by him to them— I was invited also there but did not attend— Mr Webster and Mr Saltonstall were there, and a stump speech scaffold, and it is said a procession of 6000 people or more, and a dinner of 1800. Here is a revolution in the habits and manners of the people— Where will it end? These are party movements, and must in the natural progress of things become antagonistical— At the Baltimore meeting one of the marshals of the procession was killed upon the spot— These meetings cannot be multiplied in numbers and frequency without resulting in yet deeper tragedies— Their manifest tendency is to civil war.
Sun rose and set beclouded— Fair day.

Mr Lunt though much indisposed performed all the services of both parts of this day. His morning text was from 1. Corinthians 6:20—glorify God in your body, and in your Spirit, which are God’s— A Dissertation to show how it is possible for so poor a creature as man to glorify God— By his natural disposition, his experience of the world, his failure of success in his struggles for a respected standing in society, his infirm and alarming state of health, the prospects of a destitute family to survive him, and the warnings of history. Mr Lunt has not a very favourable opinion of mankind; and being of a meek and quiet Spirit, he thinks of himself almost as humbly as of mankind generally— Piety, tenderness, benevolence, with a tinge of melancholy pervade all his Sermons, but I have never been more affected and pleased with any discourse of his than this afternoon when his text was from Ruth 1.16. “And Ruth said, Entreat me not to leave thee, or to return from following after thee: for whither thou goest, I will go; and where thou lodgest I will lodge: thy people shall be my people, and thy God my God. 17. Where thou diest will I die, and there will I be buried: the Lord do so to me, and more also, if aught but death part thee and me.”— Mr Lunt began by remarking on the peculiar character of the Book of Ruth as distinguished from all the other books of the Scriptures— He said the Bible was generally spoken of as one book; but it was a collection of many books, of very different descriptions— He then enumerated the historical, poetical, prophetical books of the old Testament, the books of Job and of the Proverbs, without mentioning the Ecclesiastes or the Song of Solomon; but considered this Book of Ruth as differing from all the rest— I consider it as belonging to the historical class, an appendage to the book of Judges, and as most essential in tracing the genealogy of David and Solomon, and of Jesus Christ— Mr Lunt dwelt upon the transcendent excellence of the character of Ruth—upon her admirable fidelity and affectionate attachment to her mother in Law—upon her fortitude in the endurance of extreme indigence; upon her active exertions in gleaning the fields for the subsistence of Naomi—and he descanted upon the wonderful vicissitudes of human events in raising from this woman of the detested race of Moab, in the deepest wretchedness of poverty, reduced to glean from a harvested field for daily bread, David and Solomon, kings of unrivalled magnificence and glory; and Jesus the Saviour of Mankind— He finally pointed the moral of his discourse, by exhorting his hearers of both sexes, and of all ages, but especially the young, to emulate those virtues which, exerted in the humblest condition of life under the severest trials with which human nature was ever afflicted, have crowned with unfading glory the name of an obscure Moabitish woman, to be revered through a thousand generations throughout the civilized world— Evening visits from Mrs Miller; her son, and Elizabeth C. Adams, Mr Beale and his daughters and E. Price Greenleaf.

Preparations for departure on our voyage to Halifax, Nova Scotia— Mr Curtis came over from Jamaica Plains to concert arrangements for our voyage.— I despatched a Letter, and a parcel of pamphlets to the Revd Josiah Adams of Parkersburg, Virginia, and a Letter to Mr Thomas Adams junr to apologize for my non-attendance, at the Norfolk County, whig Ladies Pic Nic next Thursday. There was an advertisement in this Morning’s Boston Newspapers requesting that the Passengers by the Steamer Acadia should be on board, by half past 10. to-morrow morning, and that their baggage should be sent on board this evening. but Mr Curtis said Captain Miller had told him he should leave the wharf punctually at noon.— Dijah Bowen came for his papers relating to his claim in the right of Rene Gedeon, to bounty Lands, for enlistment in the Legion of franks at New-Orleans, in February 1814. I thought and told Mr Bowen that I had left his papers on a file at Washington, to be sent round by water to Boston; but after he was gone I found the papers, and a Letter of 30 December 1839. from William Gordon, chief clerk of the Bounty Land-Office to me, adverse to the claim.— I made up a packet of all the papers, and enclosed them to Mr Bowen— DrBowditch and MrBarnard came out from Boston this afternoon and repeated an invitation renewed from last year, and which I had some weeks since received from the Warren street Association, to deliver the introductory Lecture to their course for the approaching Season.— Without positively declining, I referred them to a definitive answer after my return from my proposed excursion.— The Revd. Mr Cornell was here this Evening with youngWood; for whom I made application for a Cadet’s warrant for June 1841. when Zealous B. Tower is to vacate the place of Cadet from the 12th. Congressional District of Massachusetts— The young man is exceedingly anxious to obtain the appointment; and I promised to do all in my power to obtain it for him; giving him fair warning of the crosses, and difficulties and dangers and pernicious temptations of the life that he was aspiring to encounter, and fervently exhorted him if he should persist in his purpose and obtain the appointment, to use all his exertions to make good the place of his predecessor, who for three successive years and ever since his admission has been at the head of his class— My wife was much indisposed all this day and evening— Charles went to Boston, and returned home to dine— Miss Henshaw came out from Boston and is to stay with his wife during his absence— I spent the Evening at his house. Louisa C. Smith is sickening into the same state in which she was last Autumn, and is attended by Dr Woodward.

Day. One whole month has slip’d away, since our return from Washington home, and I have accomplished nothing— My power of writing fails more and more from day to day; and writing is to me the only labour of life.
